awd_titl_txt: Student Travel Support for Security and Human Behavior Workshop 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal is to fund student travel to the Security and Human Behavior (SHB) workshop to be held in June 2019 at Harvard University. The goals of SHB are to discuss, in an informal and interdisciplinary setting, issues where security, psychology, and behavior interact. The scope is broad: topics that have been covered in the past include the misperception of risk, security usability, deception, security and privacy decision making. As the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) research program was expanded to include social sciences in addition to its core in computer science, gatherings such as SHB provide a key venue for interaction between the different communities.

Students from U.S. universities, or U.S. students from other universities, will greatly benefit from participating in the workshop, where they will interact with research leaders from a variety of disciplines and will be exposed to the most recent developments in information security and privacy research. In particular, the first rule of the SHB Workshop is that everyone who attends actually participates in the discussion. This will ensure that students get more value from attending SHB than many conferences and workshops where they can simply listen. Further, the organizers will ask invited senior scholars for suggestions of student participants who are from underrepresented groups to invite, increasing the chance that the workshop will broaden participation in the SaTC community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The 12th edition of the Security and Human Behavior (SHB) Workshop took place at Harvard University on June 3-4, 2019. SHB is a unique venue for interdisciplinary discussions at the intersections of security, psychology, and human behavior. Previous editions of the Workshop have been held at MIT, Cambridge, USC, CMU, Harvard, and Georgetown University. The 2019 edition of the Workshop consisted in a two-day gathering of distinguished security researchers, psychologists, economists, behavioral economists, sociologists, philosophers, law scholars, and others -- all of whom either directly study, or indirectly contribute, to the understanding of the human side of security.

The Workshops' goal was to discuss, in an informal and interdisciplinary setting, issues where security, psychology, and behavior interact. The scope was broad: topics we covered included the misperception of risk, security usability, deception, security and privacy decision making, and so forth.

Funding was used to allow graduate students to travel to and participate in the Workshop. Students benefitted from participating in the Workshop, where they interacted with research leaders from a variety of disciplines and were exposed to the most recent developments in information security and privacy research.

The Workshop stimulated the sharing of cutting-edge scientific information pertaining to information security and privacy. A key defining feature and advantage of the Workshop consisted in its interdisciplinary approach to privacy and security.


Last Modified: 06/21/2024
Modified by: Alessandro Acquisti
